journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

title-group.article-title: Micronutrient, Antioxidant, and Oxidative Stress Status in Children With Severe Cerebral Palsy

article-meta.aff: 3Exercise and Oxidative Stress Research Group, School of Human Movements
4Queensland Cerebral Palsy and Rehabilitation Research Centre, The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Niikee C. Schoendorfer, Children’s Nutrition Research Centre, The University of Queensland, Royal Children’s Hospital, Herston, Australia 4029. Email: n.schoendorfer@uq.edu.au.

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition
permissions.copyright-holder: The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

abstract.p: Background: Markers indicative of micronutrient and antioxidant status in children with cerebral palsy (CP) were explored due to these children’s well-documented issues with food intake and the limited biochemical literature. Materials and Methods: Children aged 4 to 12 years with marked CP (n = 24) and controls (n = 24) were recruited. The CP group represented orally (O) or enterally fed (E) children. Concentrations of red cell folate (RCF), magnesium, superoxide dismutase (SOD), glutathione reductase, and peroxidase were measured, as well as serum methylmalonic acid and vitamin C. Plasma hemoglobin, C-reactive protein, α-tocopherol, cholesterol, zinc, protein carbonyls, and total antioxidant capacity were also quantified. Results: Data are reported as mean (SD) and z scores where values differ with age. Many similarities existed, but zinc z scores were reduced in O (–1.10 [0.83]) vs controls (–0.54 [0.54]) (P < .05), as well as for glutathione reductase in O (10.15 [1.69]) vs E (12.22 [2.41]) and controls (11.51 [1.67]) (P < .05). RCF was greatly increased in E (1422 [70]) vs O (843 [80]) and controls (820 [43]) (P < .001). SOD was decreased in E (24.3 [1.4]) vs controls (27.0 [2.8]) (P < .05). Conclusion: Considering their vast impact on physiology, micronutrients should be routinely monitored in orally fed children with swallowing disorders and dietary limitations. Excessive intakes, particularly long term in enterally fed children, should also be monitored in view of their potential for competitive inhibition, particularly at high levels.

sec.title: Clinical Relevancy Statement
sec.p: Information on micronutrient status using functional biochemical indicators is an important area of child malnutrition, considering the inherent issues using commonly practiced static testing methods. The findings of this study highlight the need for consideration to be placed on nutrition imbalances, as opposed to stand-alone issues with deficiency in children with feeding issues such as in cerebral palsy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cerebral palsy (CP) is the most common disability identified in approximately 1 per 500 live births.1 Children with CP commonly have feeding difficulties, due to involuntary muscle spasms and spasticity, which can affect their swallowing ability.2 This has a significant influence on their nutrient intake and thus general health and life expectancy.3

Optimal nutrition status may significantly affect health outcomes via its potential to improve immune system function4 and enhance healing mechanisms of both soft and connective tissues.5,6 Subclinical deficiencies are known to impair numerous biological processes, including immune function.7 Many micronutrient deficiencies, including riboflavin, folic acid, and vitamins A, B6, B12, C, and D, have been documented to inhibit the formation of specific antibodies against invading pathogens,8 and many are also required as antioxidants for free radical scavenging.9 Specific micronutrients such as vitamins A and C, as well as vitamin B6 and folic acid, seem to play a larger role in immune system function than most other nutrients, with the latter also being especially important in protein and nucleic acid metabolism.10 These particular nutrients also play a role in maintaining integrity and metabolic function of most mitotic tissues. In contrast, some of the other B vitamins more precisely function in metabolism with fewer effects on immunity.11

Aside from acting as antioxidants or immune system modulators, micronutrients are essential to intermediary metabolism as cofactors in numerous enzymatic reactions or in nonenzymatic physiological functions. These include, although are not limited to, hematopoiesis and cell proliferation and differentiation,11,12 which are essential for growth and development. Due to increasing body mass during these periods, all children have an increased need for trace elements, predominantly during rapid growth in infancy and in puberty.13 These alterations in requirement are mainly to accommodate the need for structural syntheses and enzyme production.10

Assessment of micronutrient status often relies on the quantification of element concentrations in a variety of components and cells in the blood, with this strategy based on the assumption that circulating mineral concentrations reflect organ and tissue mineral contents. Although these methods are commonly used, it has not been a sensitive approach for the evaluation of total body nutrition status of mineral elements.14

Micronutrients are also disseminated among circulating, storage, and tissue pools, depending on the chemistry of their environment. Physiologic stress, intercompartmental fluid shifts, acid-base balance, and recent dietary intake can all affect sequestration of nutrients within a particular pool. Nutrient levels in both plasma and serum may also appear to be sufficient, even when there is verification of functional impairment due to the serum concentrations of some nutrients, such as calcium and vitamin A, being strongly homeostatically regulated,15 therefore providing little information on total body status.

As much of the nutrition research in children with CP surrounds the concepts of energy and deficiency, the aim of this study was to assess body status of a range of micronutrients along with measures of antioxidant capacity and oxidative stress. Functional laboratory tests were used where appropriate and available, such as measuring the activity of enzymes that require a nutrient as a coenzyme or prosthetic group. Examination of the extent of functional impairments during a specific nutrient deficiency may have greater biological implication than the commonly used static laboratory tests.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Children with marked CP (n = 24), aged between 4 and 12 years (mean [SD], 7 years, 7 months [2 years, 6 months]), were recruited from the Royal Children’s Hospital, Brisbane, Australia. These children were classified on the Gross Motor Function Classification Scale (GMFCS) as either level IV (n = 11) or V (n = 13), which consists of children who are nonambulatory. This group was further divided into those who are orally fed (n = 15) and enterally fed (n = 9). A control group, which included age-matched, typically developing healthy children (n = 24; mean [SD] age, 7 years, 4 months [2 years]), were recruited through a range of advertising mediums. This study was conducted according to the guidelines in the Declaration of Helsinki, and all procedures involving human participants/patients were approved by the ethics committees of the Royal Children’s Hospital (2007/117), The University of Queensland (2006000409), and the Cerebral Palsy League of Queensland (2008/2009 1021). Written informed consent was obtained from all participants’ parents or guardians.
Exclusion criteria included coexistence of specific chronic diseases such as renal, cardiac, or identified metabolic disorders, as well as gastric resection, which may otherwise confound results.

Fasting blood samples were collected from participants and separated into an EDTA-anticoagulant tube for plasma zinc and hemoglobin, red blood cell magnesium, and folate. Lithium heparin plasma tubes were used for C-reactive protein, α-tocopherol, and cholesterol, with the red cells used to quantify glutathione peroxidase and reductase. Serum was collected for methylmalonic acid (MMA), homocysteine, and vitamin C, with the latter requiring further stabilization following the method used by Vuilleumier and Keck16 and adapted for a microplate reader (FLUOstar Optima; BMG Lab Tech, Ortenberg, Germany) using excitation and emission wavelengths of 355 and 460 nm, respectively.

Blood samples for additional antioxidant parameters were collected in tubes containing dipotassium EDTA, and serum was mixed in a ratio of 1:1 with a solution of 2 g dithiothreitol (DTT) and 0.2 g EDTA per liter of 350 mmol/L HClO4 as a preservative, until subsequent analysis, in accordance with the protocol previously described.17

Plasma protein carbonyls were measured as a marker for protein oxidation, in duplicate, using a microplate reader (FLUOstar Optima; BMG Lab Tech) according to published methods.18,19 Carbonyl content was calculated from absorbance at wavelengths of 370 and 650 nm and expressed relative to protein concentration, which was determined using a bicinchoninic acid protein assay (BCA Protein assay kit; Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA).

Blood plasma was analyzed for total antioxidant capacity (TAC) activity, and blood erythrocytes were analyzed for superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity using modified versions of assays described in other studies20-22 using an automated spectrophotometer (Cobas Mira; Roche, Basel, Switzerland).

Red cell folate (RCF) was tested using the folate assay (competitive binding receptor assay) on the Beckman Coulter DXi analyzer (Beckman Coulter Synchron Clinical System; Beckman Coulter, Brea, CA), whereas C-reactive protein was directly analyzed with the same instrument. Hemoglobin assessment was performed on the Sysmex XE2100 hematology analyzer (Sysmex Corporation, Kobe, Japan). Concentrations of MMA were calculated using gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC-MS) with isotope-labeled internal standards and modified methods previously described.23

The z scores were calculated for values that are known to vary with age and gender, such as plasma zinc, α-tocopherol, hemoglobin, and cholesterol. These were calculated from previously published reference material.24 A ratio of α-tocopherol to total cholesterol was used as abnormal lipid concentrations may confound the interpretation of α-tocopherol status, due to it circulating in blood mainly with low-density lipoproteins. To overcome this effect, plasma α-tocopherol levels have been correlated to lipid fractions, with the plasma α-tocopherol/cholesterol ratio found to be the most convenient to perform the indicator.25

Statistical analyses were conducted using Microsoft Office Excel 2007 (Microsoft Corp, Redmond, WA), with comparisons between means obtained via analysis of variance (ANOVA). P values were calculated via the post hoc least significant difference test. P values below .05 were considered statistically significant. As no previous data exist in this area, a sample size of 16 was selected as it would detect a statistically significant difference if the means between the groups varied by 1 standard deviation.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Participant characteristics, including anthropometric data, are outlined in Table 1. Resultant data are found in Table 2. Micronutrient status assessments via pathology testing revealed no significant differences between the groups for concentrations of red cell glutathione peroxidase as a functional measure of selenium status, red cell magnesium, hemoglobin z score, serum α-tocopherol z score/cholesterol z score ratio, protein carbonyl, or TAC was established. Red cell enzyme glutathione reductase, as a functional measure of riboflavin, was lower in orally fed children compared with the other children, whereas the activity of this enzyme after the addition of flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD effect) was significantly lower in the enterally fed children. SOD activity was also found significantly reduced in the enterally fed children compared with the other groups.

fn.p: Indicates differences between cerebral palsy groups.

sec.p: After removing zinc values that were affected by inflammation, as indicated by C-reactive protein levels, zinc was found to be lower in the orally fed group. Red cell folate was significantly higher in the enterally fed group, whereas MMA was lower in this group, suggesting adequate B12 status.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study demonstrates a range of nutrition imbalances between the groups, with orally fed children possessing particular deficiencies and enterally fed children displaying certain excesses. Reductive adaptation occurs when nutrition is imbalanced and inadequate for the body’s demands. When allowed to progress over time, its continuance leads to the impairment of cell functions, as ensuing damage can no longer be rectified by the standard compensatory mechanisms.26

The term acute phase response (APR) is used to describe a short-term metabolic change, encompassing increased plasma levels of particular proteins and decreased levels of others. These responses occur in tissue injury such as infection, surgical or other trauma, burns, tissue infarction, and a variety of idiopathic inflammatory states.27 Several frequently used indicators of micronutrient status, such as serum or plasma iron, zinc, selenium, and copper, are also affected by the APR and may not effectively reflect micronutrient status. During an APR, there can be a redistribution of micronutrients without actual alterations in the total body content, resulting in commonly used indicators producing inaccurate measurements.28

After removing the zinc values of those patients with increased inflammation and hence the concomitant changes induced by an APR, zinc was found to be significantly lower in the orally fed group. A further consideration for zinc is that it is required in sufficient amounts to maintain vitamin A status due to its regulatory role in vitamin A transport via synthesis of retinol-binding protein. Zinc is also an indispensible enzyme cofactor for the vitamin A metabolic pathway, which requires oxidative conversion from retinol to retinaldehyde, as commonly described in the visual cycle of the retina.29

Red cell enzyme glutathione reductase, as a functional measure of riboflavin, was lower in orally fed children compared with the other groups. In deficiency, this enzyme has been associated with a variety of abnormal clinical states, including spasticity.30 The FAD effect was reduced in the enterally fed group, which has been documented in conditions such as hypoplastic anemia, drug-induced hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, or a range of other disorders.31 It may also indicate sufficient riboflavin status, although in normal individuals, glutathione reductase in red cells is not saturated with its coenzyme FAD, and addition to the medium demonstrates an effect even at increasing dosages.31 An abnormally low FAD effect may occur in a negative nitrogen balance state, as erythrocytes can take up riboflavin released during tissue breakdown. This would corroborate with findings published elsewhere, documenting potential protein inadequacy in this group of enterally fed children with severe CP.32

Hemoglobin levels were also similar between the groups, which may be used as a broad overview indicator of long-term iron status. Because the range of hemoglobin values for normal nonanemic persons overlaps with values for persons with iron deficiency, hemoglobin should not be used as the only measure of iron status in individuals. Hemoglobin concentrations also fall only in late-stage iron deficiency anemia and therefore are a relatively insensitive measure of iron deficiency.33 Despite not being the most accurate measure of current iron levels, it is likely that all of the groups had adequate iron status, as iron is also essential to the enzyme glutathione peroxidase,12 which was found in sufficient levels in all groups. In light of this, we thought it low priority at this stage to investigate iron status any further.

On the other hand, the large standard deviation for hemoglobin in the enterally fed group was due to 2 children with excessive levels, accompanied also by high hematocrit and red cell counts (unpublished data). A number of the enterally fed children also had extremely elevated serum magnesium levels, and therefore the large standard deviation is once more evidenced.

SOD is an important metalloenzyme that protects lipid cell membranes from oxidation. In red cells, it is copper dependent and hence is used as a marker of copper deficiency, which has also been shown to increase through copper supplementation.34 Interestingly, previously published data on our cohort showed excessive intakes of micronutrients such as iron and zinc, which are known to affect copper absorption and/or metabolism35 and hence may be contributing to a potential copper deficiency.

Clinical signs due to insufficiencies and excesses of micronutrients occur due to longstanding changes in metabolic function. Clinical interventions generally occur once clinical signs manifest, should these be recognized.36 Marginal imbalances are, however, seldom addressed as subclinical micronutrient dysregulation can lack clinical signs altogether despite causing metabolic changes. Any alteration in metabolic function should be a convincing reason for intervention to optimize the physiological function—and hence health and well-being—of the patient.

In light of the findings outlined in this article, further research should investigate nutrition quality in these children and incorporate a myriad of nutrition components. These should also not be limited to standard assessments, as all nutrients perform vital activities in the body, which as a whole cannot function adequately in the absence of any components. There is a risk of deficiencies arising in orally fed children who are unable to consume adequate quantities of food, as is there a risk of excessive micronutrient consumption causing imbalances in enterally fed children, particularly those who are being administered high volumes in an attempt to achieve catch-up growth.
